title: Iron shoes
data:
**[English]()** • [中文（中国大陆）‎](/wiki/Iron_shoes/zh-CN "Iron shoes/zh-CN")

| \[   iron shoes   [![Iron shoes.png](/images/b/b9/Iron_shoes.png)](/wiki/File:Iron_shoes.png) |                                      |
| --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------ |
| Appearance                                                                                    | hard shoes                           |
|                                                                                               |                                      |
| Slot                                                                                          | [boots](/wiki/Boots "Boots")         |
| AC                                                                                            | [2](/wiki/Armor_class "Armor class") |
| Special                                                                                       | *(none)*                             |
|                                                                                               |                                      |
| Base price                                                                                    | 16 [zm](/wiki/Zorkmid "Zorkmid")     |
| Weight                                                                                        | [50](/wiki/Weight "Weight")          |
| Material                                                                                      | [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron")            |

A pair of **iron shoes** is a set of [boots](/wiki/Boots "Boots") that appear in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. They are naturally made of [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron"), and appear as **hard shoes** when unidentified.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Description](#Description)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Variants](#Variants)

  - [5.1 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [5.2 xNetHack](#xNetHack)
  - [5.3 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [5.4 SlashTHEM](#SlashTHEM)
  - [5.5 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [6 References](#References)

## Generation

In addition to random generation, general [stores](/wiki/Store "Store"), used armor dealerships and antique weapon outlets can sell iron shoes.

Live [dwarves](/wiki/Dwarf_\(monster_attribute\) "Dwarf (monster attribute)") have a 6⁄7 chance of [generating with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") iron shoes, and [Uruk-hai](/wiki/Uruk-hai "Uruk-hai") have a 1⁄3 chance of generating with them.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) [Orc-captains](/wiki/Orc-captain "Orc-captain") have a 1⁄2 chance of being generated with Uruk-hai armor, giving them an effective 1⁄6 chance of generating with the boots.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

[Player monsters](/wiki/Player_monster "Player monster") on the [Astral Plane](/wiki/Astral_Plane "Astral Plane") have an effective \~4.68% chance of generating with iron shoes.[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)[\[5\]](#cite_note-mk_mplayer_armor-5)

## Description

While worn, a pair of iron shoes grants 2 base [AC](/wiki/AC "AC"), and protects a character against a [xan](/wiki/Xan "Xan")'s [leg-wounding](/wiki/Wounded_legs "Wounded legs") sting 2⁄5 of the time.[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)

## Strategy

Iron shoes and [high boots](/wiki/High_boots "High boots") are the only boots to grant 2 base AC: iron shoes are much easier to find, particularly in the [Gnomish Mines](/wiki/Gnomish_Mines "Gnomish Mines"), but weigh more and incur a small [spellcasting](/wiki/Spellcasting "Spellcasting") penalty. They are additionally vulnerable to [erosion](/wiki/Erosion "Erosion") by rusting and corrosion, which among other things can make encounters with [rust monsters](/wiki/Rust_monster "Rust monster") annoying.

In the early phases of the game, melee roles with low interest in spells and casters looking to prioritize AC will likely grab one of the many pairs of iron shoes they encounter in the Mines, and may swap them for high or low boots as necessary. Their spellcasting penalty is low enough that a character can usually retain comfortably low spell failure rates if they are the only metallic armor worn.

## History

Iron shoes first appear in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

## Variants

Some variants rename the hard shoes used by dwarves to **dwarvish boots**, which may also grant an AC bonus to dwarves that wear them (including [dwarven](/wiki/Dwarf_\(starting_race\) "Dwarf (starting race)") characters), and are otherwise the same as iron shoes; other variants may additionally repurpose the iron shoes given to Uruk-hai into [orcish boots](/wiki/Orcish_boots "Orcish boots"), which may also grant an AC bonus to orcs that wear them (including [orcish](/wiki/Orc_\(starting_race\) "Orc (starting race)") characters).

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), the pair of iron shoes is simply known as a **pair of shoes** and retains its unidentified appearance.

A pair of shoes grants 1 base AC and 1 [DR](/wiki/DR "DR") while worn, and have a base [object material](/wiki/Object_materials_\(dNetHack\) "Object materials (dNetHack)") of iron - a pair of shoes always displays its material when identified, even with the default material.

Several monsters can generate with a pair of shoes:

- [Storm giants](/wiki/Storm_giant "Storm giant") are generated with a pair of iron shoes.
- [Master Kaen](/wiki/Master_Kaen "Master Kaen") is generated with a cursed +4 pair of iron shoes that have the holy, consecrated, unholy, and desecrated [object properties](/wiki/Object_properties#Offensive "Object properties").
- [Eclavdra](/wiki/Eclavdra "Eclavdra"), the [quest leader](/wiki/Quest_leader "Quest leader") for the [Drow Racial quest](/wiki/Drow_Racial_quest "Drow Racial quest") and [Hedrow shared quest](/index.php?title=Hedrow_shared_quest\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Hedrow shared quest (page does not exist)"), is generated with a blessed and erodeproofed +0 pair of [silver](/wiki/Silver "Silver") shoes.
- [Sister T'eirastra](/index.php?title=Sister_T%27eirastra\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Sister T'eirastra (page does not exist)"), the [Drow Healer quest](/index.php?title=Drow_Healer_quest\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Drow Healer quest (page does not exist)") leader, is generated with a blue-colored blessed pair of [cloth](/wiki/Cloth "Cloth") shoes.
- [Pen'a mendicants](/index.php?title=Pen%27a_mendicant\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Pen'a mendicant (page does not exist)") are generated with a blue-colored blessed pair of [cloth](/wiki/Cloth "Cloth") shoes.
- [Neferet the Green](/wiki/Neferet_the_Green "Neferet the Green") is generated with a blessed and erodeproofed +5 pair of silver shoes.
- [Nurses](/wiki/Nurse "Nurse") that are generated in the [Anachrononaut quest](/wiki/Anachrononaut_quest "Anachrononaut quest") and [Android quest](/index.php?title=Android_quest\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Android quest (page does not exist)") are generated with a +7 white-colored pair of cloth shoes.

### xNetHack

[xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack") renames iron shoes to "dwarvish boots" and retains the odds of Uruk-hai generating with them, with a comment in makemon.c suggesting that they stole their boots from dwarves.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), iron shoes are renamed to dwarvish boots and grant a +1 AC bonus to dwarves that wear them, while Uruk-hai and other [orcs](/wiki/Orc_\(monster_class\) "Orc (monster class)") are instead given orcish boots, which grant a +1 AC bonus to orcs wearing them.

[Croesus](/wiki/Croesus "Croesus") has a 1⁄2 chance of generating with a set of [gold](/wiki/Gold_\(material\) "Gold (material)") dwarvish boots.

A pair of dwarvish boots can be created at a [forge](/wiki/Forge_\(dungeon_feature\) "Forge (dungeon feature)") by combining a [dwarvish short sword](/wiki/Dwarvish_short_sword "Dwarvish short sword") and a pair of [gauntlets](/wiki/Gauntlets_\(EvilHack\) "Gauntlets (EvilHack)").

### SlashTHEM

In [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), the [militant cleric](/wiki/Militant_cleric "Militant cleric") of the rebel party that serves as [quest nemeses](/wiki/Quest_nemeses "Quest nemeses") for the default [Noble quest](/wiki/Noble_quest "Noble quest") will generate with iron shoes.

### Hack'EM

[Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM") splits iron shoes into dwarvish and orcish boots similar to EvilHack.

[Upgrading](/wiki/Upgrading "Upgrading") a pair of [high boots](/wiki/High_boots "High boots") will produce a pair of dwarvish boots. As in EvilHack, a pair of dwarvish boots can be created at a forge by combining a dwarvish short sword and a pair of gauntlets.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 417](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L417): *Uruk-hai armor and weapons*
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 370](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L370)
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 402](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L402): *switch for orc-captains*
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [src/mplayer.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 134](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mplayer.c#L134): *`special` is only set to true when generating player monsters on the Astral Plane*
5. [↑](#cite_ref-mk_mplayer_armor_5-0) [src/mplayer.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 294](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mplayer.c#L294): *this line requires `if (special)` and selects boots from all available types listed in objects.c*
6. [↑](#cite_ref-6) [src/mhitu.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1220](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mhitu.c#L1220)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")
html:
Iron shoes

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
English

 • 中文（中国大陆）‎
[   iron shoes  
Appearance hard shoes
Slot boots
AC 2
Special (none)
Base price 16 zm
Weight 50
Material iron

A pair of iron shoes is a set of boots that appear in NetHack. They are naturally made of iron, and appear as hard shoes when unidentified.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Description
  • 3 Strategy
  • 4 History
  • 5 Variants
    • 5.1 dNetHack
    • 5.2 xNetHack
    • 5.3 EvilHack
    • 5.4 SlashTHEM
    • 5.5 Hack'EM
  • 6 References

Generation

In addition to random generation, general stores, used armor dealerships and antique weapon outlets can sell iron shoes.

Live dwarves have a 6⁄7 chance of generating with iron shoes, and Uruk-hai have a 1⁄3 chance of generating with them.[1][2] Orc-captains have a 1⁄2 chance of being generated with Uruk-hai armor, giving them an effective 1⁄6 chance of generating with the boots.[3]

Player monsters on the Astral Plane have an effective ~4.68% chance of generating with iron shoes.[4][5]

Description

While worn, a pair of iron shoes grants 2 base AC, and protects a character against a xan's leg-wounding sting 2⁄5 of the time.[6]

Strategy

Iron shoes and high boots are the only boots to grant 2 base AC: iron shoes are much easier to find, particularly in the Gnomish Mines, but weigh more and incur a small spellcasting penalty. They are additionally vulnerable to erosion by rusting and corrosion, which among other things can make encounters with rust monsters annoying.

In the early phases of the game, melee roles with low interest in spells and casters looking to prioritize AC will likely grab one of the many pairs of iron shoes they encounter in the Mines, and may swap them for high or low boots as necessary. Their spellcasting penalty is low enough that a character can usually retain comfortably low spell failure rates if they are the only metallic armor worn.

History

Iron shoes first appear in NetHack 3.0.0.

Variants

Some variants rename the hard shoes used by dwarves to dwarvish boots, which may also grant an AC bonus to dwarves that wear them (including dwarven characters), and are otherwise the same as iron shoes; other variants may additionally repurpose the iron shoes given to Uruk-hai into orcish boots, which may also grant an AC bonus to orcs that wear them (including orcish characters).

dNetHack

In dNetHack, notdNetHack and notnotdNetHack, the pair of iron shoes is simply known as a pair of shoes and retains its unidentified appearance.

A pair of shoes grants 1 base AC and 1 DR while worn, and have a base object material of iron - a pair of shoes always displays its material when identified, even with the default material.

Several monsters can generate with a pair of shoes:

  • Storm giants are generated with a pair of iron shoes.
  • Master Kaen is generated with a cursed +4 pair of iron shoes that have the holy, consecrated, unholy, and desecrated object properties.
  • Eclavdra, the quest leader for the Drow Racial quest and Hedrow shared quest, is generated with a blessed and erodeproofed +0 pair of silver shoes.
  • Sister T'eirastra, the Drow Healer quest leader, is generated with a blue-colored blessed pair of cloth shoes.
  • Pen'a mendicants are generated with a blue-colored blessed pair of cloth shoes.
  • Neferet the Green is generated with a blessed and erodeproofed +5 pair of silver shoes.
  • Nurses that are generated in the Anachrononaut quest and Android quest are generated with a +7 white-colored pair of cloth shoes.

xNetHack

xNetHack renames iron shoes to "dwarvish boots" and retains the odds of Uruk-hai generating with them, with a comment in makemon.c suggesting that they stole their boots from dwarves.

EvilHack

In EvilHack, iron shoes are renamed to dwarvish boots and grant a +1 AC bonus to dwarves that wear them, while Uruk-hai and other orcs are instead given orcish boots, which grant a +1 AC bonus to orcs wearing them.

Croesus has a 1⁄2 chance of generating with a set of gold dwarvish boots.

A pair of dwarvish boots can be created at a forge by combining a dwarvish short sword and a pair of gauntlets.

SlashTHEM

In SlashTHEM, the militant cleric of the rebel party that serves as quest nemeses for the default Noble quest will generate with iron shoes.

Hack'EM

Hack'EM splits iron shoes into dwarvish and orcish boots similar to EvilHack.

Upgrading a pair of high boots will produce a pair of dwarvish boots. As in EvilHack, a pair of dwarvish boots can be created at a forge by combining a dwarvish short sword and a pair of gauntlets.

References

  1. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 417: Uruk-hai armor and weapons
  2. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 370
  3. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 402: switch for orc-captains
  4. ↑ src/mplayer.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 134: special is only set to true when generating player monsters on the Astral Plane
  5. ↑ src/mplayer.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 294: this line requires if (special) and selects boots from all available types listed in objects.c
  6. ↑ src/mhitu.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1220

Live [[Dwarf (monster attribute)|dwarves]] have a {{frac|6|7}} chance of [[monster starting inventory|generating with]] iron shoes, and [[Uruk-hai]] have a {{frac|3}} chance of generating with them.{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|417|version=NetHack 3.6.7|comment=Uruk-hai armor and weapons}}{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|370|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} [[Orc-captain]]s have a {{frac|2}} chance of being generated with Uruk-hai armor, giving them an effective {{frac|6}} chance of generating with the boots.{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|402|version=NetHack 3.6.7|comment=switch for orc-captains}} [[Player monster]]s on the [[Astral Plane]] have an effective ~4.68% chance of generating with iron shoes.{{refsrc|src/mplayer.c|134|version=NetHack 3.6.7|comment=special is only set to true when generating player monsters on the Astral Plane}}{{refsrc|src/mplayer.c|294|version=NetHack 3.6.7|name=mk_mplayer_armor|comment=this line requires if (special) and selects boots from all available types listed in objects.c}} ==Description== While worn, a pair of iron shoes grants 2 base [[AC]], and protects a character against a [[xan]]'s [[Wounded legs|leg-wounding]] sting {{frac|2|5}} of the time.{{refsrc|src/mhitu.c|1220|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} ==Strategy== Iron shoes and [[high boots]] are the only boots to grant 2 base AC: iron shoes are much easier to find, particularly in the [[Gnomish Mines]], but weigh more and incur a small [[spellcasting]] penalty. They are additionally vulnerable to [[erosion]] by rusting and corrosion, which among other things can make encounters with [[rust monster]]s annoying. In the early phases of the game, melee roles with low interest in spells and casters looking to prioritize AC will likely grab one of the many pairs of iron shoes they encounter in the Mines, and may swap them for high or low boots as necessary. Their spellcasting penalty is low enough that a character can usually retain comfortably low spell failure rates if they are the only metallic armor worn. ==History== Iron shoes first appear in [[NetHack 3.0.0]]. ==Variants== Some variants rename the hard shoes used by dwarves to '''dwarvish boots''', which may also grant an AC bonus to dwarves that wear them (including [[Dwarf (starting race)|dwarven]] characters), and are otherwise the same as iron shoes; other variants may additionally repurpose the iron shoes given to Uruk-hai into [[orcish boots]], which may also grant an AC bonus to orcs that wear them (including [[Orc (starting race)|orcish]] characters). ===dNetHack=== In [[dNetHack]], [[notdNetHack]] and [[notnotdNetHack]], the pair of iron shoes is simply known as a '''pair of shoes''' and retains its unidentified appearance. A pair of shoes grants 1 base AC and 1 [[DR]] while worn, and have a base [[Object materials (dNetHack)|object material]] of iron - a pair of shoes always displays its material when identified, even with the default material. Several monsters can generate with a pair of shoes: * [[Storm giant]]s are generated with a pair of iron shoes. * [[Master Kaen]] is generated with a cursed +4 pair of iron shoes that have the holy, consecrated, unholy, and desecrated [[Object properties#Offensive|object properties]]. * [[Eclavdra]], the [[quest leader]] for the [[Drow Racial quest]] and [[Hedrow shared quest]], is generated with a blessed and erodeproofed +0 pair of [[silver]] shoes. * [[Sister T'eirastra]], the [[Drow Healer quest]] leader, is generated with a blue-colored blessed pair of [[cloth]] shoes. * [[Pen'a mendicant]]s are generated with a blue-colored blessed pair of [[cloth]] shoes. * [[Neferet the Green]] is generated with a blessed and erodeproofed +5 pair of silver shoes. * [[Nurse]]s that are generated in the [[Anachrononaut quest]] and [[Android quest]] are generated with a +7 white-colored pair of cloth shoes. ===xNetHack=== [[xNetHack]] renames iron shoes to "dwarvish boots" and retains the odds of Uruk-hai generating with them, with a comment in makemon.c suggesting that they stole their boots from dwarves. ===EvilHack=== In [[EvilHack]], iron shoes are renamed to dwarvish boots and grant a +1 AC bonus to dwarves that wear them, while Uruk-hai and other [[Orc (monster class)|orcs]] are instead given orcish boots, which grant a +1 AC bonus to orcs wearing them. [[Croesus]] has a {{frac|2}} chance of generating with a set of [[Gold (material)|gold]] dwarvish boots. A pair of dwarvish boots can be created at a [[Forge (dungeon feature)|forge]] by combining a [[dwarvish short sword]] and a pair of [[Gauntlets (EvilHack)|gauntlets]]. ===SlashTHEM=== In [[SlashTHEM]], the [[militant cleric]] of the rebel party that serves as [[quest nemeses]] for the default [[Noble quest]] will generate with iron shoes. ===Hack'EM=== [[Hack'EM]] splits iron shoes into dwarvish and orcish boots similar to EvilHack. [[Upgrading]] a pair of [[high boots]] will produce a pair of dwarvish boots. As in EvilHack, a pair of dwarvish boots can be created at a forge by combining a dwarvish short sword and a pair of gauntlets. ==References== {{nethack-367}} [[Category:Boots]]
